skill.name: pymoo
skill.description: Multi-objective optimization framework. NSGA-II, NSGA-III, MOEA/D, Pareto fronts, constraint handling, benchmarks (ZDT, DTLZ), for engineering design and optimization problems.
skill.summary: Multi-objective optimization framework. NSGA-II, NSGA-III, MOEA/D, Pareto fronts, constraint handlin...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure knowledge skill with example scripts demonstrating legitimate optimization algorithms. Scripts only use pymoo library for mathematical computations. No file system access, network calls, or external command execution beyond standard Python imports.

content.user_title: Solve multi-objective optimization with evolutionary algorithms
content.value_statement: Engineers and researchers need to find optimal trade-offs between conflicting objectives like cost, weight, and performance. This skill provides access to NSGA-II, NSGA-III, and other evolutionary algorithms through pymoo to discover Pareto-optimal solutions for complex design problems.
actual_capabilities: Implement single and multi-objective optimization with GA, DE, PSO, and CMA-ES algorithms
Solve 2-3 objective problems using NSGA-II to generate Pareto fronts
Handle 4+ objective problems with NSGA-III and reference directions
Define custom optimization problems with constraints and multiple objectives
Apply constraint handling techniques including penalty methods and feasibility-first selection
Visualize optimization results with scatter plots, PCP, petal diagrams, and heatmaps
limitations: Requires pymoo library installation (uv pip install pymoo)
Performance depends on population size and termination criteria settings
Does not provide gradient-based optimization (use scipy for that)
Many-objective visualization limited to dimensionality reduction techniques

use_cases.title: Engineering Design Trade-offs
use_cases.description: Find optimal balance between cost, weight, strength, and performance for structural components and machine parts.

use_cases.title: Hyperparameter Optimization
use_cases.description: Optimize machine learning model parameters across multiple metrics like accuracy, inference time, and memory usage.

use_cases.title: Resource Allocation Problems
use_cases.description: Solve scheduling and resource distribution problems with conflicting objectives like time, cost, and quality.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Single-Objective
prompt_templates.prompt: Use pymoo to optimize the Sphere function with 10 variables using Genetic Algorithm. Set population size to 100 and run for 100 generations.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Objective Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Solve the ZDT1 bi-objective benchmark problem using NSGA-II in pymoo. Show the obtained Pareto front compared to the true Pareto front.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Problem
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom pymoo problem that minimizes f1 = x1^2 + x2^2 and f2 = (x1-1)^2 + (x2-1)^2 with bounds 0 <= x1, x2 <= 5. Solve with NSGA-II.

prompt_templates.title: Decision Making
prompt_templates.prompt: After obtaining a Pareto front from a multi-objective optimization, use Pseudo-Weights to select a solution with 30% weight on objective 1 and 70% weight on objective 2. Show the selected solution and its decision variables.

output_examples.input: Optimize the ZDT1 problem with NSGA-II
output: Running NSGA-II on ZDT1 bi-objective benchmark

best_practices: Set random seed (seed=1) for reproducible optimization runs
Normalize objectives to [0,1] before applying decision making methods
Choose NSGA-II for 2-3 objectives and NSGA-III for 4+ objectives
Start with smaller populations and increase if results lack diversity
anti_patterns: Using NSGA-II for many-objective problems (4+ objectives) causes poor diversity
Skipping constraint formulation as g(x) <= 0 leads to infeasible solutions
Running optimization without termination criteria wastes compute resources
Ignoring visualization of results misses insights about solution quality

faq.question: What is the difference between NSGA-II and NSGA-III?
faq.answer: NSGA-II works best for 2-3 objectives using crowding distance. NSGA-III handles 4+ objectives using reference directions for uniform Pareto front coverage.

faq.question: How many generations should I run?
faq.answer: Start with 100-200 generations. Increase for harder problems. Monitor convergence by checking if the Pareto front stabilizes between runs.

faq.question: Can I use pymoo with custom constraints?
faq.answer: Yes. Define inequality constraints as g(x) <= 0 and equality constraints as h(x) = 0 in your ElementwiseProblem subclass.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only runs local optimization computations. No data is sent externally. All scripts execute on your local machine.

faq.question: Why is my optimization not converging?
faq.answer: Try increasing population size, checking constraint formulation, using different operators, or verifying your problem scaling is appropriate.

faq.question: How does pymoo compare to scipy optimization?
faq.answer: Pymoo excels at multi-objective problems with Pareto front generation. Use scipy.optimize for single-objective gradient-based optimization.
